dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Alright, so, um, let's dive into some pretty big news from the financial world, specifically impacting, you know, foreign companies listed here in the U.S. There's been a lot of talk about this legislation.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Alright, so, um, let's dive into some pretty big news from the financial world, specifically impacting, you know, foreign companies listed here in the U.S. There's been a lot of talk about this legislation.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, definitely. We're talking about the Holding Foreign Companies Accountable Act, which, um, has really been looming over a lot of Chinese companies, in particular, for a while now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, definitely. We're talking about the Holding Foreign Companies Accountable Act, which, um, has really been looming over a lot of Chinese companies, in particular, for a while now.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: President Donald Trump signed legislation that could remove Chinese companies from U.S. exchanges if American regulators are not allowed to review their financial audits. The Holding Foreign Companies Accountable Act will require companies to establish that they are not owned or controlled by a foreign government and allow the U.S. Public Accounting Oversight Board to review their financial audits.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. The core of it is about, like, audit transparency. Basically, if American regulators, specifically the PCAOB – that's the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board – can't, uh, review these companies' financial audits...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. The core of it is about, like, audit transparency. Basically, if American regulators, specifically the P C A O B - that's the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board - can't, uh, review these companies' financial audits...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Holding Foreign Companies Accountable Act will require companies to establish that they are not owned or controlled by a foreign government and allow the U.S. Public Accounting Oversight Board to review their financial audits.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [overlapping] Which, for years, has been a huge sticking point with China, right? They've cited national security concerns for not allowing those inspections.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which, for years, has been a huge sticking point with China, right? They've cited national security concerns for not allowing those inspections.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Chinese authorities have long blocked overseas regulators from inspecting local accounting firms, citing national security concerns.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right. So, this Act essentially says, "Look, if we can't inspect your audits for three consecutive years, you're off our exchanges." It's a pretty clear ultimatum.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right. So, this Act essentially says, "Look, if we can't inspect your audits for three consecutive years, you're off our exchanges." It's a pretty clear ultimatum.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The companies have a grace period of three years to comply with the requirement before facing the threat of losing access to U.S. stock markets, a key source of capital for the companies.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And it’s not, you know, an immediate thing. There’s a grace period, like, three years for companies to actually comply before they face that potential delisting.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And it's not, you know, an immediate thing. There's a grace period, like, three years for companies to actually comply before they face that potential delisting.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The companies have a grace period of three years to comply with the requirement before facing the threat of losing access to U.S. stock markets, a key source of capital for the companies.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Which, for these companies, I mean, that's a huge potential loss of capital, losing access to the U.S. stock market. It's a massive blow.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which, for these companies, I mean, that's a huge potential loss of capital, losing access to the U.S. stock market. It's a massive blow.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The companies have a grace period of three years to comply with the requirement before facing the threat of losing access to U.S. stock markets, a key source of capital for the companies.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and while it applies to *any* non-U.S. company, let's be real, the measures are, like, pretty clearly intended for Chinese companies – think Alibaba, Pinduoduo, PetroChina.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and while it applies to any non-U.S. company, let's be real, the measures are, like, pretty clearly intended for Chinese companies - think Alibaba, Pinduoduo, PetroChina.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Although the legislation applies to companies from any country outside of the U.S., the bills measures are clearly intended to target Chinese companies, such as Alibaba Group, Pinduoduo and PetroChina.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, absolutely. And, you know, some might've hoped this would de-escalate tensions, but, uh, I'm not so sure. If anything, it adds more pressure.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, absolutely. And, you know, some might've hoped this would de-escalate tensions, but, uh, I'm not so sure. If anything, it adds more pressure.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The bill will almost certainly escalate tensions between China and the U.S. as President Trump prepares to leave office next month.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. This kind of legislation has actually had pretty strong bipartisan support, which you don't always see, especially when it comes to, you know, a tougher line on China.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. This kind of legislation has actually had pretty strong bipartisan support, which you don't always see, especially when it comes to, you know, a tougher line on China.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Legislation taking a hard line against China have been receiving bipartisan support this year amid rising tensions on a variety of fronts between the worlds two largest economies.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And, in anticipation of this, we've seen a lot of these big Chinese companies, um, pursuing primary listings in Hong Kong.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And, in anticipation of this, we've seen a lot of these big Chinese companies, um, pursuing primary listings in Hong Kong.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In anticipation of the legislation, Chinese companies have pursued secondary listings in Hong Kong as a hedge against the potential ban from trading their shares in the U.S.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, like Alibaba, NetEase, Yum China. They're basically hedging their bets, setting up shop in Hong Kong as a backup, just in case.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, like Alibaba, NetEase, Yum China. They're basically hedging their bets, setting up shop in Hong Kong as a backup, just in case.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Alibaba, NetEase and Yum China have already listed their shares in Hong Kong.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: It's smart, actually. It shows they're taking the threat of delisting from the U.S. seriously, and, uh, Hong Kong's benefiting, becoming a massive IPO market.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's smart, actually. It shows they're taking the threat of delisting from the U.S. seriously, and, uh, Hong Kong's benefiting, becoming a massive I P O market.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The citys stock exchange will finish the year as the worlds second-largest IPO market after raising a total of $50 billion in new listings, according to data compiled by KPMG.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. So, it's a really interesting dynamic. It's all about, you know, investor confidence and where these global giants decide to park their shares.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. So, it's a really interesting dynamic. It's all about, you know, investor confidence and where these global giants decide to park their shares.
